newsitem.title: NIGERIA: SOCCER-NIGERIA AT ODDS WITH DUTCH COACH OVER RESIGNATION.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-NIGERIA AT ODDS WITH DUTCH COACH OVER RESIGNATION.

text.p: Olympic champions Nigeria said on Wednesday Dutch coach Jo Bonfrere still had almost a year of his contract to run, even though he claims he resigned months ago.
"As far as we're concerned Mr Bonfrere signed a two-year contract with us in August 1995," Nigeria Football Association (NFA) spokesman Austin Mgbolu said.
But Bonfrere, who masterminded Nigeria's Olympic success in Atlanta, told the BBC by telephone: "I finished my contract with Nigeria in August after the Olympic Games.
"I gave my resignation letter to the NFA secretary and chairman, and to (soccer's world governing body) FIFA."

"I left because of some reasons which I don't want to mention in this interview," said Bonfrere, speaking from Oman where he was coaching the Qatar national side in the Gulf Cup. "But people in Nigeria know why I resigned."

Relations between the Dutchman and Nigeria's soccer authorities have been poor since January when the military government ordered the national team to boycott the African Nations' Cup in South Africa.
Nigeria, winners of the cup in Tunisia in 1994, were subsequently banned from the next two editions of the tournament. The ban was later reduced to one.

Mgbolu said the NFA expected Bonfrere to return to his post by next Monday, the day before Nigeria face Turkey in a friendly in Istanbul. Their next competitive match is a World Cup qualifier against Burkina Faso in Lagos on November 9.
"We are not aware of any resignation letter submitted by Mr Bonfrere," Mgbolu said. "He did not return from Atlanta with us, fuelling speculation then that he had resigned.
"But in September he came to (the Nigerian capital) Abuja where he met government officials and said he had not resigned. He was then given a two-month holiday for our Olympic victory."
